FacilityName: Air Liquide Electronics GPGF Malta, NY Bulk Gases

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

The substance which triggers 40 CFR 68 compliance is hydrogen, which is stored in liquid form and distributed in gaseous form.



The purpose of the Air Liquide Electronics Malta Bulk Gas hydrogen process is to supply gaseous hydrogen to our customer via pipeline on a 24 hour, 365-day basis.  The plant has a full time staff of 8 employees.  Flammable hydrogen gas is stored in liquid form in two stationary horizontal jacketed vacuum insulated cryogenic, horizontal tanks. One vessel is rated to hold 17,030 gallons and the other is rated to hold 14,480 gallons.  The liquefied hydrogen is pressured over to  the inline vaporizing and purifying equipment. The gaseous hydrogen is transferred to a customer hydrogen distribution system. 



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



The chemical specific accidental release and accident prevention steps are those to mitigate risk from flammable gases.



Employees are consulted on the conduct of process hazard analysis, trained on the process using standard operating procedures and the other elements of the risk management plan . 



The equipment was designed by engineers. Documentation pertaining to the design of the process and recommended maintenance /integrity inspections are followed.

Process hazard analysis by HAZOP has been used to identify potential concerns and ensure mitigation to low levels of risk.

If contractors are used on the site, they are pre-qualified prior to selection and trained on site specific hazards and emergency awareness for the site to ensure potential hazards of contractors are mitigated.

A safe/hot work program is used to lower risk associated with maintenance and repair.

Management of Change is used for any alterations to the system.

Pre Startup Review process (i.e., Ready for Startup Review )is used to review the initial and return to operational readiness following any significant

event such as turnaround, new construction  

An incident investigation process is applied at multiple facilities in different geographic areas facilitates for the timely review of all similar systems operated by Air Liquide ensuring identified risks are mitigated. 

An emergency action plan is utilized. All employees are trained on emergency action plan.  And emergency information is shared with local emergency planning and response groups.

Audits of the system are conducted periodically and a pre-startup review occurs prior to startup after any significant change. 

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The covered bulk tanks were designed / installed and maintained and the facility utilizes safety equipment such as:

  gauges and internal piping to ensure the bulk tanks are operated at or below maximum allowable working pressure capacity

  overpressure relief valves for pressure vessels per ASME code

  fail-closed emergency shut-off valves

  relief valves on storage vessel and process piping

  process alarms and interlocks in the downstream processes, sensitive to: flows, pressures, temperatures, and levels

  manual emergency shutdown system

  isolation valves to safeguard the system, ensure a safe range of operation and actively mitigate events that fall outside of those 

  parameters.



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:



ALEUS's bulk hydrogen process has not had an accident that has caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:



ALEUS utilizes an Emergency Action Plan, Standard Operating Procedures (SOP's), and Emergency Action Plan Training to ensure personnel are trained to identify and respond to accident and emergency situations.



ALEUS emergency response to accidental releases from the covered process includes:

  notification of all persons on site

  notif

ication of contiguous industrial site by telephone

  notification of the Globalfoundries  Emergency Response Team and the emergency response agencies by telephone

  stopping equipment and isolating any equipment which may leak flammable gases

  isolation of bulk tank via remote emergency stop

  evacuation of the area

  coordination with the Globalfoundries Emergency Response Team and the local fire department



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



As is our policy at Air Liquide Electronics U.S. LP, we continue to review our process(es) for possibilities of improvement to process, operational methods, and new technology to lower risk as part of continuous improvement.



ALEUS performs safety inspections, internal and external safety audits, process hazard analysis, risk analysis, incident and near miss investigations, behavioral audits and site observations to identify opportunities to improve the process.
